qas.question: What is need in the developing world

answers.text: Improved sanitation in the developing world is a global need

qas.question: What does data collected by unicef and Who show

answers.text: Improved sanitation in the developing world is a global need, but a neglected priority as shown by the data collected

qas.question: How many people have no sanatation facilities

answers.text: About one billion people have no sanitation facility whatsoever and continue to defecate in gutters, behind bushes or in open water bodies

qas.question: What country is the worst violator

answers.text: India is the country with the highest number of people practicing open defecation: around 600 million people

qas.question: India is host to what activity

answers.text: "Reinvent the Toilet Fair" in Delhi, India in March 2014.

plausible_answers.text: Improved sanitation in the developing world is a global need

qas.question: What is needed for the WHO?
What country has been the focus of the foundation's monitoring activities?

plausible_answers.text: Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation (JMP)

qas.question: What program monitors progress toward improved sanitation?
How many people are monitored under the JMP?
What fair took place that was hosted by the WHO?

context: <a0_0><a1_0><b5_0>Improved sanitation in the developing world is a global need<b5_0/><a0_0/>, but a neglected priority as shown by the data collected<a1_0/> by the <b7_0>Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation (JMP)<b7_0/> of UNICEF and WHO. This program is tasked to monitor progress towards the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) relating to drinking water and sanitation. <a2_0><b8_0>About one billion people<b8_0/> have no sanitation facility whatsoever and continue to defecate in gutters, behind bushes or in open water bodies<a2_0/>, with no dignity or privacy - which is called open defecation and which poses significant health risks. <a3_0>India is the country with the highest number of people practicing open defecation: around 600 million people<a3_0/>. India has also become a focus country for the foundation's sanitation activities which has become evident since the <a4_0>"<b9_0>Reinvent the Toilet Fair<b9_0/>" in Delhi, <b6_0>India<b6_0/> in March 2014.
